00019 /**
00020  @page simulator OCTEON Simulator
00021 
00022 @section sim_contents Contents
00023 
00024 - @ref sim_overview
00025 - @ref sim_running

00032 
00033 
00034 @section sim_overview Overview
00035 
00036 
00037 The files "bin/pp" and "cn3*xx-simulator*" are the the OCTEON simulators and "bin/oct-sim" is the wrapper
00038 script that is typically used to invoke the simulator.  The simulator provides a
00039 functional and performance simulator for Cavium Network's OCTEON
00040 processor.  Detailed information on the simulator can be found in the
00041 "OCTEON Simulator" whitepaper.  The oct-sim script uses the OCTEON_MODEL
00042 environment variable to select what member of the OCTEON family to simulate.
00043 
00044 
00045 @section sim_running Running the OCTEON Simulator
00046 
00047 First, build the 'hello' example in 'examples/hello':
00048 
00049 @code
00050     make hello
00051 @endcode
00052 
00053 To run this application on the simulator, use the following command:
00054 
00055 @code
00056     oct-sim hello -quiet
00057 @endcode
00058 
00059 
00060 To run this on multiple cores, add the -numcores=NUM option to the command
00061 line.  Each core will run in its own memory space, with private stack,
00062 heap, and local data.  Read only code and data are mapped to a shared
00063 region for all cores.
00064 
00065 Running hello produces a good deal of output, including the line:
00066 @code
00067     PP0:~CONSOLE-> Hello world!
00068 @endcode
00069 
00070 Statistics like these also come out:
00071 @verbatim
00072 PP0 Model 1 Estimated performance.
00073 Instructions Issued               ->   1036  30.5%
00074 Bubbles due to no pipe swapping   ->    139   4.1%
00075 Bubbles due to single issue LD/ST ->    149   4.4%
00076 Bubbles due to single issue Branch->     61   1.8%
00077 Bubbles due to single issue other ->      4   0.1%
00078 Bubbles due to RAW                ->    230   6.8%
00079 Bubbles due to unaligned ld/st    ->      0   0.0%
00080 Bubbles due to mul/div busy       ->     10   0.3%
00081 Bubbles due to crypto  busy       ->      0   0.0%
00082 Bubbles due to llm busy           ->      0   0.0%
00083 Bubbles due to BR taken           ->    152   4.5%
00084 Bubbles due to JR taken           ->     46   1.4%
00085 Bubbles due to BR mispredict      ->    148   4.4%
00086 Bubbles due to MTCOP0 stall       ->     35   1.0%
00087 Bubbles due to Ifetch             ->   2694  79.2%
00088 Bubbles due to BRfetch            ->    152   4.5%
00089 Bubbles due to Dmiss              ->    458  13.5%
00090 Bubbles due to Dmiss with Wbuf hit->   1380  40.6%
00091 Bubbles due to Write Buf Avail    ->      0   0.0%
00092 Bubbles due to sync               ->     96   2.8%
00093 Bubbles due to delay slot dual    ->     11   0.3%
00094 Bubbles due to io lds             ->      0   0.0%
00095 Total Cycles (no zombie)          ->   3400 100.0% (   3400)
00096 @endverbatim
00097 
00098 Showing that 1036 instructions issued in the 3400 cycles that the
00099 simulator executed for this Mips core.  Note that the total of the first
00100 columns ("Instructions Issued" + "Bubbles *") approximately equals twice
00101 the number of cycles since OCTEON is dual-issue.
00102 
00103 You also get stats like:
00104 @verbatim
00105 Memory fills                            ->     52 (utilization 12.232%)
00106 Memory writebacks                       ->      0 (utilization 0.000%)
00107 L2 store bus cycles                     ->     72 (utilization 2.117%)
00108 L2 address bus cycles                   ->     69 (utilization 2.029%, L2C ctl utilization 4.058%)
00109 L2 fill bus cycles                      ->    188 (utilization 5.528%)
00110 @endverbatim
00111 
00112 Which display some interesting CB, L2C, and local DRAM bus utilizations.  Please see
00113 the sections @ref core_statistics and @ref system_statistics below for
00114 a detailed description of simulator performance statistics.
00115 
00116 You can get more detail in the text output with:
00117 @code
00118     oct-sim hello
00119 @endcode
00120 
00121 which will give output like:
00122 @verbatim
00123  PP0:20009C40<vfprintf+376>:2091@1        : [7040102b] SNE     $v0, $v0, $zero [$v0=1]
00124  PP0:20009C44<vfprintf+380>:2092@0        : [  431024] AND     $v0, $v0, $v1 [$v0=1]
00125  PP0:20009C48<vfprintf+384>:2093@0~SL     : [1440fff5] BNE     $v0, $zero,  20009C20<vfprintf+344>
00126  PP0:20009C4C<vfprintf+388>:2093@1        : [       0] NOP
00127  PP0:20009C20<vfprintf+344>:2095@0~BR     : [afc003e8] SW      $zero, 1000($fp) [(7FFFEB88,7FFFEB88)=0]  MEM[0x7FFFEB88]<- 0x0(mask=FFFFFFFF00000000)
00128  PP0:20009C24<vfprintf+348>:2096@0~SL     : [92620000] LBU     $v0, 0($s3) [$v0=A(2011CAFC<_libc_intl_domainname+2572>,2011CAFC)]
00129  PP0:20009C28<vfprintf+352>:2098@0~RAW    : [  501024] AND     $v0, $v0, $s0 [$v0=0]
00130  PP0:20009C2C<vfprintf+356>:2099@0~SL     : [14400ebe] BNE     $v0, $zero, 2000D728
00131  PP0:20009C30<vfprintf+360>:2099@1        : [67c603e8] DADDIU  $a2, $fp, 1000 [$a2=7FFFEB88]
00132  PP0:20009C34<vfprintf+364>:2100@0        : [66730001] DADDIU  $s3, $s3, 1 [$s3=2011CAFD]
00133  PP0:20009C38<vfprintf+368>:2101@0~SL     : [92620000] LBU     $v0, 0($s3) [$v0=0(2011CAFD<_libc_intl_domainname+2573>,2011CAFD)]
00134 @endverbatim
00135 
00136 Showing the individual instructions that execute, the cycle #, the binary
00137 instruction, the mnemonic, and some additional description.
00138 
00139 Or you can do:
00140 @code
00141     oct-sim hello -quiet -vz
00142 @endcode
00143 
00144 To create an octeon.vz file for later visual examination with the
00145 viewzilla tool.
00146 
00147 @section magic Simulator "magic"
00148 
00149 The simulator provides some 'magic' functions for performance and
00150 convenience that are unique to the simulator environment.  These functions
00151 are called as normal C functions, but are handled specially by the
00152 simulator.  When an instruction at a certain address
00153 (currently 0xfeffe000) is executed, the simulator traps this and executes
00154 code providing various services.  Since these functions rely on simulator
00155 tricks and a Linux host, they cannot be provided when running on real
00156 hardware.
00157 
00158 The current special functions are:
00159 
00160 - simprintf(char *format,...)
00161 
00162     This function passes the format string and
00163     arguments to the native printf() in the simulator.  No string processing
00164     or argument conversion is simulated, so it is much faster.  The
00165     implementation is very simple, as a result there are significant
00166     limitations on the usage:
00167     -# maximum of 7 arguments.  (more than this requires pulling arguments off
00168         of the stack.)
00169     -# all format specifiers must be of the form %ll, or incorrect results
00170         will be printed.  This is a result of the native printf being run on a
00171         32-bit machine, and the register values being 64 bit.  If the ll is not
00172         specified, the native printf pulls the arguments off the stack at 32-bit
00173         offsets, instead of 64-bit offsets, resulting in incorrect results.
00174         Warnings will be printed if any format specifiers are not %ll.
00175     -# The number of arguments is determined by counting '%' characters, so
00176         you cannot print '%' characters in your output.
00177     -# No buffering is done - each simprintf call results in immediate output
00178 
00179 - int open(const char *pathname, int flags)
00180 - int close(int fd)
00181 - int read(int fd, void *buf, size_t count)
00182 - int write(int fd, const void *buf, size_t count)
00183 
00184     These four system calls are mapped to use the host systems file system.
00185     Normal files can be read and written through these system calls.  Also, C
00186     library functions that use these functions can be used.  Using these calls
00187     on stdout, stderr, or stdin is not supported.
00188 
00189 
00190 @section oct-sim oct-sim (simulator wrapper script)
00191 
00192 @verbatim
00193 Usage: oct_sim octeon_executable [-memsize=size] [-envfile=filename] [-debug] \
00194                  [-stacksize=0xXXXX] [-heapsize=0xXXXX] [-appargs="args for application"] [simulator options]
00195 
00196 oct-sim option descriptions:
00197          -memsize=size          size is in megabytes.  Defaults to 128 megabytes.
00198          -envfile=filename      u-boot will load environment from file 'filename'.
00199          -debug                 enables debugging of application.
00200          -stacksize=0xXXX       sets stack size in bytes for simple exec applications (1 MB default)
00201          -heapsize=0xXXX        sets heap size in bytes for simple exec applications (3 MB default)
00202          -appargs="arg string"  passes "arg string" to application as argc/argv
00203 
00204 @endverbatim
00205 
00206 The OCTEON SDK provides the oct-sim wrapper script to simplify the usage
00207 of the simulator for running simple executive based applications.  The
00208 oct-sim script is the preferred way to invoke the simulator.  The
00209 script loads the u-boot bootloader at the correct address, and places the
00210 user program at the address that the bootloader expects it.  The script
00211 also passes the memory size that is simulated to the bootloader.  The
00212 oct-sim script passes all unrecognized options to the simulator.
00213 
00214 The oct-sim script provides the follow additional arguments:
00215 
00216 - -memsize=DRAM_size    Specify DRAM size in megabytes.  Default DRAM size
00217 is 128 Megabytes.  DRAM is only simulated at the correct physical
00218 addresses based on the amount of DRAM simulated.
00219 
00220 - -envfile=filename specifies an alternate environment for the u-boot
00221             bootloader.  This allows various bootloader
00222 parameters to be adjusted at runtime.  Currently the only environment
00223 variable that is used is the 'bootcmd' variable, and this can be used
00224 to change the address from which the application is loaded, and the stack
00225 and heap size that the application is allocated.  The format of the file
00226 is a string of the form "bootcmd=bootoct 0x10000000 stack=0x3000
00227 heap=0x3000" (without the quotes).  The hello example provides an example
00228 of using the environment file to specify stack and heap sizes.
00229 
00230 - -debug    Enable debugging of the application with GDB.
00231 
00232 - -stacksize=0xXXXXX  Sets the stack size in bytes for simple exec applications.  This
00233 allows the stack size for the application to be configured at runtime.
00234 
00235 
00236 - -heapsize=0xXXXXX  Sets the heap size in bytes for simple exec applications.  This
00237 allows the heap size for the application to be configured at runtime.
00238 
00239 - -appargs="arg string" Specifes the command line arguments to be passed to the simple
00240  exec application.  The string is added to the end of the bootloader command, parsed
00241  by the bootloader, and passed to the application main() routine as argc/argv.
00242 
00243 
00244 
00245 @section sim_args Simulator Arguments
00246 
00247 Below are the arguments supported by the OCTEON simulator and a brief
00248 description of each.  Invoking oct-sim without any arguments will display
00249 the usage for the currently configured simulator.  The simulators for each
00250 of the OCTEON models have slightly different options.
00251 
00252 @verbatim
00253 
00254 
00255         -quiet[=cycle]     Don't display instructions executed until the specified cycle. If cycle is ommitted instructions will not be displayed.
00256         -trace=[...]       Enable tracing for specific features/units.
00257         -modes=[...]       Enable particular hardware modes.
00258         -numcores=cpus     Control the number of processors simulated. Defaults to one.
00259         -maxcycles=cycles  Terminate simulation after a set number of cycles.
00260         -maxperfcycles=cyc Terminate simulation after the performance model has run a set number of cycles.
00261         -maxperfinsts=cnt  Terminate simulation after the performance model has run a set number of instructions.
00262         -maxtracecycles=cyc Terminate simulation a set number of cycles after -wait is true.
00263         -maxtraceinsts=cnt Terminate simulation a set number of instructions after -wait is true.
00264         -numbbs=cnt        Control the number of basic blocks the performance model prints. Defaults to 0.
00265         -uart0=port        Listen on the supplied TCP port for a connection for UART0
00266         -uart1=port        Listen on the supplied TCP port for a connection for UART1
00267         -serve=port        Listen on the supplied TCP port for connections for Packet I/O
00268         -freq=speed        Specify the core clock speed in MHz (default = 500)
00269         -memdatarate=speed Specify the main memory data rate in MHz (default = 533)
00270         -pci=port          Listen on the supplied TCP port for a connection for PCI bus emulation
00271         -ld=address:file   Setup main memory at the supplied address with the supplied file.
00272         -ld=address:bytes  Setup main memory at the supplied address with bytes zeroes.
00273         -llsize=words      Initialize low latency memory of the supplied size (in 36-bit words) with zeros.
00274         -ll=file           Initialize low latency memory with the contents of the supplied file.
00275         -vz[=file]         Enable viewzilla output
00276         -log               Enable additional logging
00277         -noperf[=symbol|cycle] Disable cycle performance characterization for improved speed. If symbol|cycle are present,
00278                            performance characterization is disabled only until execution passes the supplied symbol or cycle count.
00279         -wait=symbol|cycle Don't start instruction tracing or viewzilla until execution passes the supplied symbol or cycle count.
00280         -idle              Terminate the simulation if all processors are idle and no POW work is available.
00281         -l2inst            force all instruction references to appear to hit in L2 cache (and remove one of the 8 L2 ways)
00282 
00283         All number may either be specified as decimal "10", hexadecimal "0xA", or octal "012".
00284 
00285 @endverbatim
00286 
00287 Additional arguments for the CN78XX simulator are:
00288 
00289 @verbatim
00290     -numnodes=node_count
00291     -memsize=node0mem,node1mem
00292 
00293     See -ldaddress:file for more information on multinode executive loading.
00294 @endverbatim
00295 
00296 <b>-quiet[=cycle]</b>
00297 
00298 Don't produce the more verbose textual output indicating each core
00299 instruction that is executed.  If this argument does not exist, the
00300 verbose textual output will start after the wait period.  Note that
00301 verbose output can be very large for long simulation runs.  (Use -wait
00302 to reduce it.) If the cycle argument is supplied, the simulator does not
00303 print out instructions until the selected cycle.  If "-trace" is not
00304 otherwise supplied, this command turns off all tracing.
00305 
00306 <b>file</b>
00307 
00308 "file" is an ELF file to be loaded into memory before running the
00309 simulator.  The simulator allocates memory regions corresponding the
00310 sections in the ELF file and loads the appropriate data into the memory.
00311 The simulator assumes that the virtual addresses in the ELF file are the
00312 physical addresses that should be used.  Physical memory locations not
00313 allocated by either an ELF section load or by "-ld" (see below) do not
00314 exist and cause errors when referenced.
00315 
00316 <b>-trace=[fau,fpa,packet,pow,tag,pip,pko,lreg,dfa,dfb,wb,tlb,iob,all]</b>
00317 
00318 Determines how much the simulator prints out about the operation of
00319 various hardware units:
00320 
00321     - fau = print fetch and add updates
00322     - fpa = print free pool operations
00323     - packet = when "-serve" is not used, print out packet data
00324     - pow = print POW work movements
00325     - tag = print POW tag switch operations
00326     - pip = print work queue creation (via "-serve")
00327     - pko = print PKO packet output steps
00328     - lreg = print changes to CVMSEG LM
00329     - dfa = print coarse DFA engine behavior
00330     - dfb = print detailed (state-by-state) DFA engine behavior
00331     - wb = print when core memory stores become visible (i.e. exit the write buffer)
00332     - tlb = print out detailed core TLB information on each update
00333     - iob = print memory references that originate from the IO bus
00334     - all = print all of the above
00335 
00336 <b>-noperf</b>
00337 
00338 Run simulator with functional modeling only, no performance modeling.
00339 
00340 <b>-wait=label|cycle</b>
00341 
00342 Do not gather statistics, print verbosely, nor generate viewzilla output
00343 until an instruction with a symbol of label or the selected cycle count is
00344 executed.  For example, "-wait=cvm_process_packet" will cause the
00345 simulator to wait until the first instruction from the
00346 cvm_process_packet() routine is executed before printing out instruction
00347 or viewzilla traces.
00348 
00349 <b>-vz</b>
00350 <b>-vz=file</b>
00351 
00352 Generate output for viewzilla after the wait period.  If file is not
00353 supplied, "octeon.vz" is used.  E.g.  "-vz" produces "octeon.vz",
00354 "-vz=myvzfile.vz" produces "myvzfile.vz".  Note that viewzilla output can
00355 be very large for long simulation runs.  (Use -wait to reduce it.)
00356 
00357 <b>-numcores=N</b>
00358 
00359 Simulate with N cores instead of 1. E.g. "-numcores=2".
00360 
00361 <b>-serve=port</b>
00362 
00363 Allows the simulator to emulate packet receipt and transmit (through the
00364 GMX/SPX packet interfaces) through information transferred over a TCP
00365 connection.  When this option is used, the simulator acts as a server for
00366 the selected TCP port.  More than one client can connect to the simulator
00367 via the port.  Each client specifies the SPX/GMX ports it will receive
00368 packets for.  (Exactly one client must receive output packets for a given
00369 SPX/GMX port.) The appendix describes the details of the information
00370 transferred over the TCP connection.
00371 
00372 <b>-uart0=port,-uart1=port</b>
00373 
00374 Allows the simulator to receive and send bytes via the simulated uarts.
00375 The ports specify the TCP ports that the simulator will wait for a connect
00376 on.  Exactly one client must connect to the port.
00377 
00378 <b>-l2inst</b>
00379 
00380 Assume that all instruction references to the L2 cache hit in one of the 8
00381 sets.  The remaining 7 sets are used for data references.
00382 
00383 <b>-llsize=X</b>
00384 
00385 Create a low-latency DRAM area (starting at low-latency address 0) of size
00386 X words.  E.g.  "-llsize=4096" creates a 4096 x 36-bit low-latency memory,
00387 "-llsize=0x4000" creates a 0x4000 x 36-bit low-latency memory.  By
00388 default, no low-latency memory exists, and an error will result on a
00389 reference to it.  Only "-ll" commands allocate it.
00390 
00391 <b>-ldaddress:file</b>
00392 
00393 Allocate a memory region Load the binary contents of "file" into local
00394 memory (byte) address "address".  E.g.  "-ld0x200000:myfile" will load
00395 the binary contents of "myfile" at physical memory address 0x200000.  The
00396 size of the allocated region is the size of the file.  Memory addresses
00397 nominally do not exist, and will cause a simulation error when if accessed
00398 unless it was allocated by this command or an ELF file load.
00399 
00400 Note: For 
00401 
00402 <b>-ldaddress:size</b>
00403 
00404 ex: -ld0x200000000:0x10000 will cause 0x10000 bytes of memory at address
00405 0x200000000 to be simulated and be filled with zeros.
00406 
00407 <b>-llfile</b>
00408 
00409 Create a low-latency DRAM area and preload it with the contents of "file".
00410 "file" must be a binary file - each 8 bytes in the file correspond to
00411 one 36-bit low-latency memory location.
00412 
00413 <b>-log=[std,cmb,sep]</b>
00414 
00415 This option controls how the simulator logs the standard output generated
00416 by the cores.  By default, all output goes to stdout of the simulator,
00417 with text similar to 'PP5:~CONSOLE->' prepended to each line.  The 'sep'
00418 option enables separate logging for each core, while the 'cmb' option
00419 enables logging of all the cores' output to a single file.  If either
00420 separate or combined logging is selected, output from the cores is not
00421 copied to the simulator stdout unless the 'std' option is selected.
00422 (log=std is equivalent to the default behavior)
00423 
00424 <b>-maxcycles=[cycle count]</b>
00425 
00426 Specify the maximum number of cycles that will be simulated.  The
00427 simulator will exit after the specified number of cycles, and will print a
00428 message indicating that it exited for this reason.
00429 
00430 <b>-idle</b>
00431 
00432 When this option is selected, simulation will stop soon after there is no
00433 available work.
00434 
00435 <b>-modes=[spi0,spi1,packetstd,fastboot,pass1,pass2,...]</b>
00436 This field allows control of various simulator options.  Some common ones are set by
00437 default by the oct-sim script.
00438 
00439     - spi0 = interface 0 is SPI4.2 rather than RGMII
00440     - spi1 = interface 1 is SPI4.2 rather than RGMII
00441     - packetstd = send output packets to stdout rather than -serve socket
00442     - fastboot = make boot bus references complete instantly.  This is set by oct-sim by default to speed up booting.
00443     - pass1 = simulate pass 1 silicon
00444     - pass2 = simulate pass 2 silicon
00445     - fullperf: Prints out L2 per-set and DRAM per-bank statistics.
00446     - pktXX: This allows PCI packets to flow in/out via the usual -serve=port path that is used for non-PCI packets.
00447     - pktstd: When set and -serve=port is not used, the simulator will simply print out the packets that you send out.
00448     - spi0, spi1:  Set specified interface to SPI mode instead of RGMII (only applies to models with SPI interfaces.)
00449     - XXXl2:  Set L2 size to specified size.  This is set by the oct-sim wrapper based on the OCTEON_MODEL environment variable.
00450     - cryptovz: Generate viewzilla output for crypto unit.
00451     - pass*:  Selects with silicon revision to simulate.  This is properly set by the oct-sim wrapper based on the setting of OCTEON_MODEL.
00452     - fastboot: Makes boot bus accesses instantaneous to increase simulation performance.  This is set by default in the oct-sim wrapper to speed up booting.
00453     - no*: Simulate chips with specified block disabled.  This allows simulation EXP/NSP/... Octeon models.
00454     - narrowpackage: Sets the DDR interface width to the narrow width supported by the smaller package.  This is set by the oct-sim wrapper based on the OCTEON_MODEL environment variable.
00455 
00456 
00457 
00458 @section packet_io OCTEON Simulator Live Packet Input and Output
00459 
00460 The OCTEON simulator can accept TCP connections to a particular TCP port
00461 when the "-serve" option is used.  The data travelling over these
00462 connections transfer packets into and out of OCTEON as if they arrived via
00463 the GMX/SPX interfaces.  Applications can use as many client TCP
00464 connections as they like with "-serve".  The OCTEON SDK utility
00465 "oct-packet-io" provides a simplified interface for simualtor packet IO
00466 supporting multiple packet sources. The rest of this section documents
00467 the use of the simulator packet IO directly, without oct-packet-io.
00468 
00469 The simulator does not currently support unbuffered operation on the TCP
00470 channel.  To prevent deadlock, clients may need to receive bytes from
00471 their inbound TCP connection before they can send bytes on their outbound
00472 TCP connection.
00473 
00474 <h3>Initialization Line</h3>
00475 
00476 Immediately after connecting, the client must send a mask that indicates
00477 the OCTEON internal output ports that the TCP connection wishes to
00478 receive packets for.  For example, the input line: 0xf000f indicates that
00479 OCTEON will direct output packets destined for OCTEON internal ports
00480 0,1,2,3,16,17,18,19 to this connection.  (OCTEON internal ports 0,1,2,and
00481 3 are ports 0-3 on GMX0/SPX0/XAUI0.  OCTEON internal ports 16,17,18, and 19
00482 are ports 0-3 on GMX1/SPX1/XAUI1.) The internal ports are different for 
00483 ebb6800 processor, each ports are passed in a sequence separated by comma 
00484 to simulator instead of input line. Based on the input packet, the simulator
00485 reads packets from that SGMII/XAUI interface and writes packets to that 
00486 particular SGMII/XAUI interface. The following table describes the internal
00487 port used by simulator as well as the software:
00488 
00489     INTERFACE   QLM   PORT NUMBER
00490    ------------------------------------------------------------------
00491      SGMII       0     2048,2064,2080,2096
00492      XAUI        0     2112
00493      SGMII       2     2560,2576,2592,2608
00494      XAUI        2     2624
00495      SGMII       3     2816,2832,2848,2864
00496      XAUI        3     2880
00497      SGMII       4     3072,3088,3104,3120
00498      XAUI        4     3136
00499      ILK         1     1024,1025,1026,1027,1028,1029,1030,1031,1032
00500      ILK         2     1028,1029,1030,1031,1032,1033,1034,1035,1036
00501    ------------------------------------------------------------------
00502 
00503 The masks for multiple TCP connections must not overlap.  OCTEON will wait 
00504 and eventually time out if no client connection receives the packets for a 
00505 port that needs to send a packet.
00506 
00507 <h3>Normal Operation Lines</h3>
00508 
00509 There are four legal lines after initialization.  The description below is
00510 for the OCTEON simulator receiving packets from an external client.  All
00511 of it also applies in the opposite direction for the client receiving
00512 packets from the OCTEON simulator.
00513 
00514 <h3>Release Backpressure</h3>
00515 
00516 If any line that starts with an integer in the range 128 through 163, that
00517 line indicates that back-pressure is no longer applied to output ports 0
00518 through 35, respectively.  (sent_value = 128 + port) OCTEON is free to
00519 send out the selected output port after it receives a RELEASE
00520 BACKPRESSURE.
00521 
00522 @verbatim
00523 Example lines:
00524     130              // RELEASE for port 2
00525     0x90             // RELEASE for port 16
00526 @endverbatim
00527 
00528 RELEASE BACKPRESSURE can be sent at any time (and for any port).  When the
00529 OCTEON simulator wants to release backpressure for an internal input port
00530 ID, it sends a RELEASE BACKPRESSURE to the client that is receiving
00531 packets for the output port with the same ID.
00532 
00533 <h3>Force Backpressure</h3>
00534 
00535 If any line that starts with an integer in the range 64 through 99, that
00536 line indicates that back-pressure should be applied to output ports 0
00537 through 35, respectively.  (sent_value = 64 + port) OCTEON will eventually
00538 stop sending out the selected output port after it receives a FORCE
00539 BACKPRESSURE.
00540 
00541 @verbatim
00542 Example lines:
00543     67               // FORCE for port 3
00544     0x51             // FORCE for port 17
00545 @endverbatim
00546 
00547 FORCE BACKPRESSURE can be sent at any time (and for any port).  When the
00548 OCTEON simulator wants to assert backpressure for an internal input port
00549 ID, it sends a FORCE BACKPRESSURE to the client that is receiving packets
00550 for the output port with the same ID.
00551 
00552 <h3>Start Packet</h3>
00553 
00554 Packets are transferred with one START PACKET and a number of PACKET WORD
00555 transfers.  Their lines look like this:
00556 
00557 @code
00558     <port>   <bytes>   <cycles>
00559 @endcode
00560 
00561   - port   = The input port that the simulator should receive
00562            the packet on.
00563   - bytes  = The number of bytes in the packet.
00564   - cycles = The number of internal OCTEON cycles that
00565            will be consumed on the input port by the
00566            packet.
00567 
00568 @verbatim
00569 Example lines:
00570     3 111 500       // the packet arriving on port 3 is
00571                     // 111 bytes and will consume 500
00572                     // cycles on the input port
00573     31 567 780      // the packet arriving on port 31 is
00574                     // 567 bytes and will consume 780
00575                     // cycles on the input port
00576 @endverbatim
00577 
00578 START PACKET can only be sent at the start of the packet.  After a START
00579 PACKET, the client must eventually send exactly ((bytes+7)/8) PACKET WORD
00580 transfers on the selected port before it can send another START PACKET.
00581 Data from multiple packets cannot be interleaved in the TCP stream when
00582 the two packets are destined for the same port.  (Note also that it is
00583 illegal for two different clients to send in interleaved packets destined
00584 for the same port.) START PACKET and PACKET WORD transfers for different
00585 ports can be freely interleaved, however.
00586 
00587 <h3>Packet Word</h3>
00588 
00589 PACKET WORD transfers are:
00590 
00591 @code
00592    <port>   <64-bit word>
00593 @endcode
00594 
00595 The 64-bit word is big-endian format - the first byte is the
00596 most-significant one.
00597 
00598 @verbatim
00599 Example lines:
00600    3  0xbaddeed00deeddab
00601    31 345698
00602 @endverbatim
00603 
00604 Example Normal operation lines
00605 
00606 A 40 (+14 for ether hdr) byte TCP (somewhat real) packet on port input 0:
00607 
00608 @verbatim
00609    0 54 2000
00610    0 0x5cff23c698694873
00611    0 0xdc51456708004508
00612    0 0x0028000040000806
00613    0 0x0000329fabcd3489
00614    0 0x6300000700030000
00615    0 0x0000000000005010
00616    0 0x0
00617 @endverbatim
00618 
00619 Interleaving two bogus packets to input ports 7 and 18, with back-pressure
00620 twiddling (on and off) for output ports 7 and 8:
00621 
00622 @verbatim
00623    7 111 5600
00624    7 0x235762395
00625    7 3569375
00626    71
00627    7 4687046849
00628    7 8426784567
00629    18 67 3000
00630    7 0x243275693745
00631    7 0x32ab84367288426
00632    18 429375635
00633    0x12 2359376539745
00634    7 7325374965
00635    0x7 23536259347
00636    7 23457350734
00637    7 23452395767345
00638    18 0x35932573487
00639    72
00640    18 7432537465375
00641    18 73952736573
00642    18 0x3453475
00643    7 23569237569357
00644    135
00645    7 0x3756923745
00646    18 0x37456356
00647    18 7892735635
00648    136
00649    18 0x237569237563
00650    7 372965375
00651    7 0xbe3472955635748
00652 @endverbatim
00653 
00654 <h3> Notes on simulator packet IO</h3>
00655 
00656 The simulator models, roughly, gigabit ethernet output speeds on a single
00657 output port.  The output packet rate is limited this way, and the cycles
00658 value indicates this also.
00659 
00660 Packets from multiple ports may share the same TCP connection, but it may
00661 not be desirable.  The simulator stops receiving bytes from the TCP input
00662 stream whenever a START PACKET stalls.  (The usual START PACKET stall
00663 condition will be when the prior packet is still consuming the input port.
00664 This would happen if the cycles value for the prior packet is large.)
00665 Consequently, it may be appropriate to put packets from different ports on
00666 different TCP connections.  The simulator continues to execute cycles even
00667 when a TCP connection is stalled by a START PACKET.
00668 
00669 It may also be desirable for back-pressure indications to go on a separate
00670 TCP channel to avoid the same START PACKET stalls.
00671 
00672 
00673 @section core_statistics Per core performance statistics from the simulator
00674 
00675 @verbatim
00676 PP0 Estimated performance.
00677 @endverbatim
00678 
00679 The following stats are for core 0.
00680 
00681 @verbatim
00682  Instructions Issued               -> 596173  51.7%
00683 @endverbatim
00684 
00685 The above says that there were 596173 instruction issues
00686 in the selected area, and that this was 0.52 instruction
00687 issues every cycle. This is 25% of the maximum possible
00688 two instructions per cycle.
00689 
00690 @verbatim
00691  Bubbles due to no pipe swapping   ->  89299   7.7%
00692 @endverbatim
00693 
00694 CnMIPS assigns the oldest instruction to pipe 0. This
00695 says that 0.08 issues per cycle (3.8% of the max possible
00696 two issues per cycle) may have been lost because
00697 of this fixed placement. Some instructions, like
00698 loads/stores, branches, etc. can only issue on pipe 0.
00699 
00700 @verbatim
00701  Bubbles due to single issue LD/ST -> 287846  25.0%
00702 @endverbatim
00703 
00704 This says that 0.25 issues per cycle (12.5% of the
00705 max possible two issues per cycle) may have been lost because
00706 cnMIPS only supports one memory operation per cycle.
00707 
00708 @verbatim
00709  Bubbles due to single issue Branch->  16582   1.4%
00710 @endverbatim
00711 
00712 This says that 0.01 issues per cycle (0.7% of the
00713 max possible two issues per cycle) may have been lost because
00714 cnMIPS only supports one memory operation per cycle.
00715 
00716 @verbatim
00717  Bubbles due to single issue other ->    189   0.0%
00718 @endverbatim
00719 
00720 This says that few issue slots were lost because
00721 cnMIPS cannot dual-issue trap, MT/MF, and SYNC
00722 instructions.
00723 
00724 @verbatim
00725  Bubbles due to RAW                ->   6169   0.5%
00726 @endverbatim
00727 
00728 This says that few issue slots were lost solely
00729 because the operands were not available in the
00730 input registers.
00731 
00732 @verbatim
00733  Bubbles due to unaligned ld/st    ->     56   0.0%
00734 @endverbatim
00735 
00736 OCTEON HW unaligned loads/stores take two issue slots. This
00737 says that there were few unaligned loads/stores.
00738 
00739 @verbatim
00740  Bubbles due to mul/div busy       ->   1157   0.1%
00741 @endverbatim
00742 
00743 This says that few issue issue slots may have been
00744 lost due to the multiplier or divide units being
00745 busy.
00746 
00747 @verbatim
00748  Bubbles due to crypto  busy       ->    504   0.0%
00749 @endverbatim
00750 
00751 This says that few issue issue slots may have been
00752 lost due to the COP2 units being busy, excluding LLM. This can
00753 be due to either reading the result from the unit
00754 before it has been calculated by the HW, or writing
00755 the unit before it has finished the previous operation.
00756 
00757 @verbatim
00758  Bubbles due to llm busy           ->      0   0.0%
00759 @endverbatim
00760 
00761 This says that no issue slots were lost due to accessing
00762 one of the two LLM units. This can
00763 be due to either reading the result from one of the units
00764 before it is available from the LLM, or writing
00765 the unit before it has finished the previous operation.
00766 
00767 @verbatim

00769 @endverbatim
00770 
00771 This says that few issue slots were lost solely
00772 due to taken branches that are correctly predicted.
00773 
00774 @verbatim

00776 @endverbatim
00777 
00778 This says that few issue slots were lost solely
00779 due to taken jumps (either correctly or incorrectly
00780 predicted).
00781 
00782 @verbatim

00784 @endverbatim
00785 
00786 This says that few issue slots were lost solely
00787 due to taken branches that are incorrectly predicted.
00788

00791 @endverbatim
00792 
00793 This says that few issue slots were lost solely
00794 due to move-to-COP0 (MTCOP0) instructions. MTCOP0
00795 instructions take 3 cycles (6 issues slots).

00799 @endverbatim

00802 max possible two issues per cycle) may have been lost
00803 due to instruction fetch issues, which normally accumulate
00804 due to icache misses.

00818 max possible two issues per cycle) may have been lost because

00872 should be 200%, corresponding to 2 issues per cycle.

00876 @endverbatim

00878 This will typically not be too far from to "Bubbles due to Ifetch"
00879 above.

00881 @verbatim

00883 @endverbatim
00884 
00885 A zombie is a core that is waiting for work (from POW)
00886 when work is not available. This is the non-zombie, non-wait
00887 cycle count.

00931 
00932 Mostly self-explanatory. Some notes:
00933   - "Loads" and "Stores" count the ones to L2/DRAM only
00934   - "Local Mem" is CVMSEG LM
00935   - "IO" is equivalent to non-cached
00936   - L2 fills to Icache(all) is the total number of icache
00937     fills. (prefetches) counts only the istream fills
00938     initiated by an istream prefetch

00941 @verbatim

00945 @endverbatim

00950 out by a load match.

00954 @endverbatim

00957 by this core.

00967 @endverbatim

00980 @endverbatim
00981 
00982 Indicates the branch and jump pc's that had the most mispredicts.
00983 
00984 @verbatim
00985  Icache had (28 33 32 30 ) 123 misses.
00986  Icache had (0 0 0 0 ) 0 replacements.
00987  Icache had (0 0 0 0 ) 0 fill invalidates.
00988  Icache had (0 0 0 0 ) 0 all invalidates.
00989 @endverbatim
00990 
00991 The numbers in the () are for the sets inside the four different
00992 quadrants of the icache. The last number is total.
00993    misses           = The number of misses
00994    replacement      = The number of blocks that were valid when they were re-used
00995    fill invalidates = Ignore it. Should rarely happen.
00996    all invalidates  = Counts the number of blocks whose valid bit was cleared
00997                       due to an CACHE/SYNCI instruction invalidate or instruction
00998                       address error.
00999 
01000 @verbatim
01001  Dcache had 8233 misses (repl=8172,hstall=0,lalias=0,salias=0,inv=1,fillinv=0,allinv=0,tlbinv=0,lmeminv=0).
01002 @endverbatim
01003 
01004   repl = The number of blocks that were valid when they were re-used in the dcache.
01005   hstall = Ignore this.
01006   lalias = The number of loads that found an alias in the dcache.
01007   salias = The number of stores that found an alias in the dcache.
01008   inv+fillinv = The number of invalidates recieved.
01009   allinv = Counts the number of dcache blocks whose valid bit was cleared due to an
01010            CACHE instruction or Status[ERL] change.
01011   tlbinv = Counts the number of dcache blocks whose valid bit was cleared due to an
01012            eviction of a TLB entry.
01013   tlbinv = Counts the number of dcache blocks whose valid bit was cleared due to
01014            increasing the CVMSEG LM size.
01015 
01016 @verbatim
01017  -----------------------------------------------

01026 @endverbatim

01135 
01136 <h3> Additional statistics available with "-modes=fullperf":  </h3>
01137 
01138 
01139 @verbatim
01140  L2 Per-Set Statistics
01141  ----------------------------------------
01142  0x000: memfills=          11 memfillsthru=           0 writebacks=          10 writethrus=           0
01143  0x001: memfills=          12 memfillsthru=           0 writebacks=          11 writethrus=           0
01144  0x002: memfills=          12 memfillsthru=           0 writebacks=          10 writethrus=           0
01145  0x003: memfills=           9 memfillsthru=           0 writebacks=           9 writethrus=           0
01146  0x004: memfills=           9 memfillsthru=           0 writebacks=           9 writethrus=           0
01147  ...
01148 @endverbatim
01149 
01150 Indicates the individual statistics for each set in the L2 cache.
01151   memfills     = reads of main memory into L2
01152   memfillsthru = reads of main memory into L1 cache, but not L2
01153   writebacks   = the number of dirty blocks that were replaced
01154   writethrus   = the number of full cache block writes that were not put into L2
01155 
01156 @verbatim
01157  DDR Per-Bank Statistics
01158  ----------------------------------------
01159  0: reads=        2091 writes=        2082
01160  1: reads=        2093 writes=        2082
01161  2: reads=        2092 writes=        2092
01162  3: reads=        2086 writes=        2081
01163 @endverbatim
01164 
01165 Similar individual stats for each of the four main memory banks.
